name: Pattern_Components
shortDescription: Learn the five components of the airport traffic pattern and how they work together
prompt: You are teaching a student pilot the anatomy of the airport traffic pattern at Reid-Hillview Airport (KRHV). This is their introduction to pattern operations at a busy controlled airport with parallel runways. Cover the five pattern components: departure/upwind, crosswind, downwind, base, and final. Explain the purpose of each leg, standard altitudes, airspeeds, spacing, and how to identify position. Emphasize that the pattern is a structured flow that keeps traffic organized and safe. Use both ground-based observation and airborne demonstration. KRHV has parallel runways 31L/13R and 31R/13L, pattern altitude is 1,000 feet AGL (approximately 1,135 MSL).
openingLine: Today we learn the traffic pattern - the organized flow that makes safe airport operations possible. Ready to master the pattern at a busy airport?

phases.name: Brief
phases.prompt: Brief the student on the traffic pattern structure. Explain that the pattern is a rectangular flight path around the airport that provides organized, predictable traffic flow. Introduce the five components: departure (upwind), crosswind, downwind, base, and final. Explain that most patterns are left-hand (left turns) unless specified otherwise. Cover standard pattern altitude at KRHV (1,000 AGL, approximately 1,135 MSL) and typical speeds. Emphasize that understanding the pattern is fundamental to all airport operations.
steps: Introduce the concept: the traffic pattern is a rectangular path around the runway
Explain the five legs: departure/upwind, crosswind, downwind, base, final
Describe left-hand vs right-hand patterns (KRHV uses left patterns for most runways)
State pattern altitude: 1,000 feet AGL (1,135 MSL at KRHV)
Discuss typical pattern speeds: 80-90 knots cruise, 70-80 on base, 65-70 on final
Explain the purpose: safety through predictability and organization
Mention that KRHV is busy with parallel runways, good for learning
goals: Student understands the pattern is a rectangular flight path
Student knows the five pattern components by name
Student knows pattern altitude and approximate speeds
Student understands the pattern organizes traffic for safety
Student is ready to learn each component in detail

phases.name: Ground_Observation
phases.prompt: If practical, have the student observe the pattern from the ground or tower perspective. Point out aircraft at different positions in the pattern. Help them visualize the rectangular shape and identify which leg each aircraft is on. This ground-based perspective helps them understand the overall flow before flying it themselves.
steps: Position where pattern can be observed (ramp, tower view, or simulator external view)
Point out the runway in use (likely 31L or 31R based on winds)
Identify aircraft on departure climbing out
Point out aircraft turning crosswind (90 degrees from runway)
Show aircraft on downwind (parallel to runway, opposite direction)
Identify aircraft turning base (perpendicular to runway again)
Point out aircraft on final approach (aligned with runway)
Discuss spacing between aircraft and how pattern maintains separation
goals: Student can visualize the rectangular pattern shape
Student can identify which leg an aircraft is on
Student understands the flow from departure through final
Student appreciates the spacing and organization

phases.name: Airborne_Setup
phases.prompt: Position the aircraft above pattern altitude (approximately 2,500 feet MSL) in the KRHV area to observe the pattern from above. From this vantage point, the student can see the rectangular shape clearly and watch traffic flow through each leg. Establish a safe orbit above the pattern.
steps: Use setPosition if needed to place aircraft at 2,500 MSL over KRHV
Establish a gentle orbit (right turns to keep airport in view on left side)
Point out the runway orientation and parallel runways
From above, trace the pattern shape with hands or pointer
Watch actual traffic if present, or describe traffic flow
Identify each pattern leg from this overhead perspective
Discuss how being 1,500 feet above pattern keeps us clear of traffic
goals: Student has clear view of pattern from above
Student can trace the rectangular pattern visually
Student sees how pattern relates to runway and surrounding area
Student understands vertical separation from pattern traffic

phases.name: Departure_Upwind
phases.prompt: Teach the departure or upwind leg. This is the leg from takeoff until turning crosswind, typically extending runway centerline. Explain that after takeoff, aircraft climb straight ahead maintaining runway heading until reaching at least 500-800 feet AGL (or airport-specific altitude) before turning crosswind. At KRHV, turn crosswind when approximately 800 feet AGL. The purpose is obstacle clearance and predictability for following traffic.
steps: Define departure/upwind: from takeoff to crosswind turn
Explain the climb: maintain runway heading, climb at Vy (79 knots)
Discuss altitude for crosswind turn: typically 800 feet AGL at KRHV
Explain why we climb straight: obstacle clearance, predictability
Mention following traffic spacing: they know where you will be
Discuss trim and configuration: clean, full power, climbing
Point out ground references for departure leg alignment
goals: Student understands departure leg is straight extension of runway
Student knows when to turn crosswind (approximately 800 AGL)
Student knows to maintain runway heading during departure
Student understands obstacle clearance and spacing purposes
commonErrors: Turning crosswind too early (before safe altitude)
Not maintaining runway heading (drifting with wind)
Poor speed control during climb

phases.name: Crosswind_Leg
phases.prompt: Teach the crosswind leg. This is a 90-degree turn from departure, perpendicular to the runway. The leg should be approximately 45 seconds to 1 minute long. Continue climbing toward pattern altitude (1,000 AGL). At KRHV, turn crosswind around 800 AGL and level off at pattern altitude during or just after crosswind. Purpose is to position for downwind entry and continue climb safely.
steps: Define crosswind: 90-degree turn from departure, perpendicular to runway
Demonstrate the turn: coordinated 20-30 degree bank to pattern direction (usually left)
Explain timing: turn when approximately 800 AGL or when 45-degree from runway numbers
Discuss altitude: continue climb, level at pattern altitude (1,000 AGL, 1,135 MSL)
Explain speed: reduce to 80-90 knots as approaching pattern altitude
Discuss length: typically 45 seconds to 1 minute on crosswind
Point out ground references perpendicular to runway
goals: Student understands crosswind is 90-degree leg from departure
Student knows when to turn crosswind (approximately 800 AGL)
Student knows to level at pattern altitude during or after crosswind
Student understands typical leg length (45 seconds to 1 minute)
commonErrors: Turning crosswind before reaching safe altitude
Not leveling at pattern altitude (too high or too low)
Poor wind correction (drifting toward or away from airport)
Crosswind leg too long or too short

phases.name: Downwind_Leg
phases.prompt: Teach the downwind leg. This is the leg parallel to the runway, flying opposite direction to landing. At pattern altitude (1,000 AGL), cruise speed (80-90 knots). The downwind leg provides time for landing setup: configure aircraft, run checklists, report position to tower. Position should be approximately half to three-quarters mile from the runway. Key reference: when abeam the landing threshold (numbers alongside you), begin preparing for base turn.
steps: Define downwind: parallel to runway, opposite landing direction
Demonstrate the turn: another 90-degree turn onto downwind
Explain altitude: maintain 1,000 AGL (1,135 MSL) precisely
Explain speed: 80-90 knots cruise
Discuss spacing from runway: half to three-quarters mile
Teach the abeam point: when threshold is directly off your wing
Explain downwind tasks: configure, checklist, radio calls, watch for following traffic
Point out ground references parallel to runway
goals: Student understands downwind is parallel to runway, opposite direction
Student maintains 1,000 AGL precisely on downwind
Student knows proper spacing from runway
Student recognizes abeam point (threshold alongside)
Student understands downwind is preparation phase for landing
commonErrors: Altitude not precise (too high or too low)
Too close or too far from runway
Not identifying abeam point correctly
Forgetting to prepare for landing (checklists, configuration)

phases.name: Base_Leg
phases.prompt: Teach the base leg. Turn base when approximately 45 degrees past the landing threshold (when runway numbers are 45 degrees behind the wing). Base is perpendicular to runway, descending and slowing. Begin descent to approximately 800 feet, reduce speed to 70-80 knots, may add first increment of flaps (10 degrees). Base leg length varies with wind and allows final approach alignment. Watch for traffic on final and adjust spacing.
steps: Define base: perpendicular to runway, descending to final approach
Explain when to turn: approximately 45 degrees past threshold (varies with wind)
Demonstrate base turn: 30-degree bank, coordinated, look for final approach traffic first
Discuss descent: begin descending to approximately 800 feet
Explain speed reduction: 70-80 knots on base
Discuss flaps: may add 10 degrees on base for better control
Explain length adjustment: longer base if high or fast, shorter if low or slow
Teach to watch for traffic on final and adjust spacing
goals: Student understands base is perpendicular to runway, descending
Student knows when to turn base (approximately 45 degrees past threshold)
Student begins descent and slows to 70-80 knots on base
Student considers adding first increment of flaps
Student watches for final approach traffic before turning
commonErrors: Turning base too early or too late
Not looking for traffic on final before turning
Descending too rapidly or too slowly
Poor speed control
Not adjusting base leg for wind

phases.name: Final_Approach
phases.prompt: Teach the final approach leg. Turn final to align with runway centerline. This is the most critical leg: stabilized approach at proper speed (65-70 knots with appropriate flaps), proper descent rate (approximately 400-500 fpm), aligned with centerline, on glidepath (typically 3 degrees). Full landing configuration with full flaps. This is where landing actually happens, so precision matters. Emphasize stabilization by 300-500 feet AGL.
steps: Define final: aligned with runway centerline, descending to landing
Demonstrate final turn: roll out on centerline, coordinated turn
Explain landing configuration: full flaps (30 degrees), landing speed (65-70 knots)
Discuss descent rate: approximately 400-500 fpm for typical 3-degree glidepath
Teach stabilized approach criteria: on speed, on centerline, on glidepath by 500 feet
Explain what to look for: runway alignment, VASI/PAPI lights if equipped, aim point
Discuss go-around decision: if not stabilized, go around
Point out this leg extends from turn to touchdown (typically 1-2 miles)
goals: Student understands final is aligned with runway, descending to landing
Student knows landing configuration: full flaps, 65-70 knots
Student knows stabilized approach criteria
Student understands this is the landing leg, precision required
Student knows go-around is an option if unstable
commonErrors: Not aligned with centerline
Airspeed too fast or too slow
Descent rate too high (steep) or too low (shallow)
Not stabilized by 500 feet
Continuing unstable approach instead of going around

phases.name: Pattern_Integration
phases.prompt: Now that all five legs are explained, fly one complete pattern at KRHV (observation flight, instructor or autopilot can fly). Point out each leg as you progress through it. Have the student call out which leg you are on and what the key tasks are for that leg. This integration helps cement the complete picture of how all legs connect.
steps: Set up for departure from KRHV runway 31L or 31R
Execute departure/upwind: climb straight, maintain runway heading
Ask student: what leg are we on? What should we be doing?
Execute crosswind turn: 90 degrees left, continue climb
Ask student: what leg now? What altitude should we reach?
Execute downwind: level at 1,000 AGL, parallel to runway
Ask student: what should we do on downwind? When is abeam point?
Execute base turn: 45 degrees past threshold, descend, slow, add flaps
Ask student: what leg? What configuration changes?
Execute final turn: align with centerline, full flaps, landing speed
Ask student: what makes a stabilized final?
Complete pattern by landing or going around for another pattern
goals: Student can identify each pattern leg during flight
Student understands the flow from one leg to the next
Student knows key tasks and configurations for each leg
Student sees how all five components form complete pattern
Student is prepared to fly the pattern themselves in future lessons

phases.name: Debrief
phases.prompt: Review all five pattern components with the student. Quiz them on key points: altitudes, speeds, purposes of each leg. Discuss common traffic pattern errors and how to avoid them. Emphasize that the pattern is the foundation of all takeoff and landing operations. Answer questions and preview next lesson: normal takeoffs.
steps: Ask student to name the five pattern legs in order
Quiz on pattern altitude at KRHV (1,000 AGL)
Quiz on typical speeds: departure climb, downwind cruise, base, final
Ask about key reference points: when to turn crosswind, abeam point, when to turn base
Discuss why the pattern matters: safety through organization
Review what makes a stabilized final approach
Answer any remaining questions
Celebrate learning the pattern structure
Preview next lesson: Challenge 2.2 - Normal Takeoffs
goals: Student can recite the five pattern legs in order
Student knows standard altitudes and speeds
Student understands purpose and flow of the pattern
Student recognizes key decision points in the pattern
Student feels confident in pattern knowledge and ready for takeoff practice
